It's not the emotion you experience that help form habits, but the competence and clarity you develop in performing the behavior. That sense of capability produces a feeling of success, which reinforces the desire to repeat it.

Using analogies in explanation to make complex ideas more intelligible to reader can be misleading if they are taken as actual explanations, and they can distort the deeper truth. They often give the impression that we understand something when we don’t truly grasp its essence.

What looks like random change is actually a tightly controlled process, shaped by internal preselection within its own system—not pre-fitted to external conditions, but emerging from complex internal order.

☃︎

It’s no use going back to yesterday because I was a different person then.

—— Alice, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

Welcome to Jekyll!

You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Thesis vs Art, Firm stance vs Exploration

A thesis requires a firm stance, backed by logic and evidence. In contrast, art allows for exploration, through internal contradictions or imagined dialogues.

Chapter 3: Plato - Power and Competence. [[A History of Western Thought]]. Page 59-60

Theory of ideas is a defence of objective ethics

It can be seen as a fundamental defence of an objective ethics.

[[Plato’s theory of ideas]] [[All different value systems are different ways of accessing Platonic goodness]]

#frombook #excerpt

The road of philosophy

for it [philosophy] does not admit of [[Exposition]] like other branches of knowledge; but after much converse about the matter itself and a life lived together, suddenly a light, as it were, is kindled in one soul by a flame.

Chapter Plato. In [[A History of Western Thought]]. Page range.

Plato's view of the gender

One interpretation of Plato’s view of the problems of gender is that Plato actually feared women and their sphere. He was attempting to eradicate women’s traditional sphere, as if they were an uncontrollable force with the power to form children and young people.

_Chapter 3: Plato - men and women. [[A History of Western Thought]]. Page _

#excerpt

Plato's Theory of ideas

The ideas, such as the circle and triangle, are not grasped with our senses; they are intelligible through our reason. The particular circles and triangles that we perceive with our senses are like perishable representations of the corresponding ideas. The ideas are universal and unchangeable, in contrast to the changeable representations. The ideas are not something within our thoughts. They exist objectively; they are universally valid.

Chapter 3: Plato - ideas and knowledge. [[A History of Western Thought]]. Page

#excerpt

Plato's Fundamental defence of objective ethics

If the universe is ‘divided into two’, that is, if there are two forms of existence - the things that we perceive with our senses and [[Plato’s theory of ideas|the ideas]] - then we have already prepared the ground for a universally valid ethics. We have then, in a way, explained how it is possible to say that the good exists as something objective - that is , in the form of an idea.

Chapter 3: Plato - ideas and knowledge. [[A History of Western Thought]]. _Page _

#excerpt

Art transcends the world of sensation

Things in the world of sense perception do not change rapidly, but human imagination and abstract understanding are limitless and can reach far beyond the sensory world. Therefore, art needs to go beyond the sensation world and reach directly to the true reality—the world of ideas.

Chapter 3: Plato - The ethical responsibility of the arts. [[A History of Western Thought]]. Page
